question: What element has the chemical symbol 'Au'?
funFact: Gold's symbol comes from the Latin word 'aurum'. It has been prized for thousands of years and never tarnishes.

question: How many bones does an adult human body have?
funFact: Babies are born with about 270 bones, which gradually fuse. Adults end up with exactly 206.

question: What is the speed of light in a vacuum?
funFact: Light travels so fast it could circle Earth about 7.5 times in just one second.

question: Which planet has the most moons in our solar system?
funFact: Saturn has over 146 confirmed moons — overtaking Jupiter in 2023. Many are tiny captured asteroids.

question: What gas do plants absorb during photosynthesis?
funFact: Plants absorb CO₂ and release oxygen as a byproduct. A single tree can absorb up to 48 pounds of CO₂ per year.

question: What is the hardest natural substance on Earth?
funFact: Diamond scores 10 on the Mohs hardness scale — the only thing that can scratch a diamond is another diamond.

question: How many chromosomes do humans have in each cell?
funFact: Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes (46 total). Chimpanzees actually have 24 pairs — one more than us!

question: Which is the nearest star to Earth besides the Sun?
funFact: Proxima Centauri is 4.24 light-years away. Travelling at the speed of light, it would still take over 4 years to arrive.

question: Which organ in the human body produces insulin?
funFact: The pancreas regulates blood sugar by producing insulin. Type 1 diabetes occurs when it stops making insulin entirely.

question: What is the most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere?
funFact: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of the atmosphere. Oxygen is second at 21%. CO₂ is less than 0.05%.

question: How long does it take Earth to orbit the Sun?
funFact: The extra 0.25 day is why we add a leap day every 4 years — otherwise our calendar would drift out of sync with the seasons.

question: What is the most common blood type worldwide?
funFact: Type O positive is the most common blood type worldwide. Type O negative is the universal donor for red blood cells.

question: Which blood type is considered the universal donor?
funFact: O negative red blood cells can be given to anyone regardless of blood type — making it precious in emergencies.

question: What is the powerhouse of the cell?
funFact: Mitochondria produce ATP, the molecule that powers almost every function in your cells. They have their own DNA.

question: What does DNA stand for?
funFact: Each human cell contains about 2 meters of DNA — coiled and packed into a nucleus just 6 micrometres wide.

question: Who developed the theory of relativity?
funFact: Einstein's theory of relativity changed our understanding of space, time, and gravity — and led to the famous equation E=mc².

question: On which planet does a day last longer than its year?
funFact: Venus rotates so slowly that a day there lasts 243 Earth days, while its year is only 225 Earth days.

question: Which of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World still stands today?
funFact: The Great Pyramid of Giza is the only ancient wonder still intact — built around 2560 BCE, it stood as the tallest structure for 3,800 years.

question: In what year did World War II end?
funFact: World War II ended in 1945 — in Europe on May 8 (V-E Day) and in the Pacific on September 2 (V-J Day).

question: Who was the first person to walk on the Moon?
funFact: Neil Armstrong took his first steps on July 20, 1969, saying: 'That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind.'

question: Which ancient civilization built Machu Picchu?
funFact: Machu Picchu was built in the 15th century by the Inca emperor Pachacuti. It was abandoned and unknown to outsiders until 1911.

question: Who painted the Mona Lisa?
funFact: Leonardo painted the Mona Lisa between 1503 and 1519. It now hangs in the Louvre, Paris, behind bulletproof glass.

question: In what year did the Berlin Wall fall?
funFact: The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989, after East Germany opened its borders following massive public protests.

question: Who was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize?
funFact: Marie Curie won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903, then Chemistry in 1911 — the only person to win in two scientific fields.

question: Who is credited as the principal author of the US Declaration of Independence?
funFact: Thomas Jefferson was the principal author. Franklin and Adams also contributed, but Jefferson wrote the famous first draft.

question: The Hundred Years' War was fought between which two countries?
funFact: The Hundred Years' War actually lasted 116 years (1337–1453). It featured Joan of Arc as a key French leader.

question: In what year did the Titanic sink?
funFact: The Titanic struck an iceberg on April 14, 1912, and sank in under 3 hours. About 1,500 lives were lost.

question: Who was Napoleon Bonaparte's first wife?
funFact: Joséphine de Beauharnais married Napoleon in 1796. He later divorced her in 1809 because she had produced no heir.

question: Which country was first to grant women the right to vote?
funFact: New Zealand granted women the right to vote in 1893, making it the first self-governing country in the world to do so.

question: In what year did the French Revolution begin?
funFact: The French Revolution began in 1789 with the storming of the Bastille on July 14 — now celebrated as Bastille Day in France.

question: Who was the first Roman Emperor?
funFact: Augustus (Octavian) became the first Roman Emperor in 27 BCE after defeating Mark Antony and Cleopatra.

question: Which civilization developed the world's first known writing system?
funFact: The Sumerians of ancient Mesopotamia (modern Iraq) developed cuneiform writing around 3200–3000 BCE.

question: What was the first artificial satellite launched into space?
funFact: Sputnik 1 was launched by the Soviet Union on October 4, 1957, kick-starting the Space Age and the space race.

question: In which battle was Napoleon Bonaparte finally defeated in 1815?
funFact: Napoleon's defeat at Waterloo ended his rule. The phrase 'meeting your Waterloo' now means facing a decisive defeat.

question: What is the capital of Australia?
funFact: Many assume Sydney is the capital, but Canberra was chosen as a compromise between Sydney and Melbourne in 1908.

question: Which is the longest river in the world?
funFact: The Nile stretches about 6,650 km through northeastern Africa. The Amazon rivals it in length but wins for water volume.

question: How many countries are there in Africa?
funFact: Africa has 54 recognized countries — the most of any continent. Nigeria is the most populous with over 200 million people.

question: What is the smallest country in the world by area?
funFact: Vatican City covers just 0.44 km² inside Rome. It has its own postal service, radio station, and railway.

question: Which country has the most natural lakes?
funFact: Canada has over 60% of the world's fresh water lakes — more than any other country on Earth.

question: In which ocean is the Mariana Trench located?
funFact: The Mariana Trench reaches a depth of about 11 km — deeper than Mount Everest is tall. It's the deepest point on Earth.

question: What is the capital of Canada?
funFact: Ottawa has been Canada's capital since 1857 — chosen by Queen Victoria partly for its defensive location.

question: Which country has the longest coastline in the world?
funFact: Canada's coastline stretches over 202,000 km — more than any other country. It borders three oceans.

question: What is the largest continent by area?
funFact: Asia covers about 44.6 million km² — nearly 30% of Earth's land surface and home to 60% of the world's population.

question: What is the capital of Brazil?
funFact: Brasília replaced Rio de Janeiro as Brazil's capital in 1960 — it was purpose-built from scratch in just 41 months.

question: Which country owns the Canary Islands?
funFact: Despite being closer to Africa, the Canary Islands are an autonomous community of Spain. They were named after dogs (canis).

question: Which desert is the largest in the world by area?
funFact: Antarctica is technically the world's largest desert (14.2 million km²). The Sahara is the largest hot desert.

question: In which country is Machu Picchu located?
funFact: Machu Picchu sits at 2,430 meters in the Peruvian Andes. American historian Hiram Bingham brought it to global attention in 1911.

question: What is the official language of Brazil?
funFact: Brazil is the world's largest Portuguese-speaking country. Almost every other South American nation speaks Spanish.

question: What is the capital of Japan?
funFact: Tokyo became Japan's capital in 1869. Its metropolitan area has over 37 million people — the world's most populous urban area.

question: Which mountain range contains Mount Everest?
funFact: The Himalayas span five countries and contain all 14 of the world's 8,000-metre-plus peaks.

question: What is the nickname of New York City?
funFact: New York has been called 'The Big Apple' since the 1920s. 'The Windy City' is Chicago; 'City of Angels' is Los Angeles.

question: What is the fastest land animal?
funFact: Cheetahs can accelerate from 0 to 100 km/h in about 3 seconds — faster than most sports cars.

question: How many hearts does an octopus have?
funFact: An octopus has 3 hearts: two pump blood to the gills, one to the body. Its blood is blue due to copper-based haemocyanin.

question: What is the largest land animal on Earth?
funFact: African elephants can weigh up to 7 tonnes. Their trunks contain over 40,000 muscles and no bones.

question: Which animal has the best sense of smell of any land animal?
funFact: Bears have up to 2,100 times better sense of smell than humans — about 7 times more sensitive than a bloodhound.

question: What is the only mammal capable of true, sustained flight?
funFact: Flying squirrels and sugar gliders only glide. Bats are the sole mammals with wings for powered flight.

question: How many legs does a spider have?
funFact: Spiders have 8 legs, which distinguishes them from insects (6 legs). They're arachnids, not insects.

question: What is the tallest living animal?
funFact: Giraffes can grow up to 6 metres tall. Their hearts weigh about 11 kg to pump blood 3 metres up to the brain.

question: Approximately what percentage of Earth's oceans have been explored?
funFact: We know more about the surface of Mars than the ocean floor. About 80% of Earth's oceans remain unmapped.

question: How many eyes does a bee have?
funFact: Bees have 5 eyes: 2 large compound eyes for detecting movement and colour, and 3 simple eyes (ocelli) for light detection.

question: Which is the world's largest reptile?
funFact: Saltwater crocodiles can exceed 6 metres in length and weigh over 1,000 kg. They're found across Southeast Asia and northern Australia.

question: What is the world's smallest bird?
funFact: The bee hummingbird of Cuba is just 5–6 cm long and weighs about 2 grams — lighter than a coin.

question: How long does it typically take a plastic bottle to decompose?
funFact: Plastic bottles can take 450+ years to fully break down, which is why plastic pollution is such a persistent global issue.

question: Which tree species includes the world's oldest known individual living organism?
funFact: Methuselah, a bristlecone pine in California, is about 5,000 years old — making it the world's oldest known living tree.

question: What percentage of Earth's surface is covered by water?
funFact: Earth is about 71% water — but only 3% of that is fresh water, and most of that is locked in ice.

question: Which is the world's largest mammal?
funFact: Blue whales are the largest animals ever known to have existed — reaching 30 metres and 200 tonnes.

question: What is the national animal of Scotland?
funFact: The unicorn has been Scotland's national animal since the 12th century — symbolising purity, power, and independence.

question: Which bird is known for its ability to mimic human speech most accurately?
funFact: African grey parrots have cognitive abilities similar to a 5-year-old child and can learn hundreds of words.

question: How many players from each team are on a basketball court at a time?
funFact: Five players per team are on the court in basketball. NBA teams can have up to 15 players on their roster.

question: In which city were the first modern Olympic Games held?
funFact: The first modern Olympics were held in Athens, Greece in 1896 — 1,503 years after the ancient Olympics were last held.

question: What does 'love' mean in tennis scoring?
funFact: The word 'love' for zero may come from the French 'l'œuf' (egg), because a zero looks like an egg.

question: How many times has Brazil won the FIFA World Cup?
funFact: Brazil won in 1958, 1962, 1970, 1994, and 2002 — making them the most successful World Cup team in history.

question: How many rings are on the Olympic flag?
funFact: The five rings represent the five inhabited continents. At least one of the six flag colors appears in every national flag.

question: What is the maximum score possible in a single dart turn (3 throws)?
funFact: Three triple-20s scores the maximum 180. Professional players call this a 'maximum' — it's extremely rare.

question: How many holes are in a standard round of golf?
funFact: An 18-hole round became standard when St Andrews reduced its course from 22 holes in 1764.

question: Who is credited with coining the phrase 'the beautiful game'?
funFact: Pelé, the Brazilian legend who won three World Cups, popularised calling football 'the beautiful game'.

question: In which country was the martial art of judo invented?
funFact: Judo was created by Jigoro Kano in Japan in 1882. It became an Olympic sport at the 1964 Tokyo Games.

question: How many points is a touchdown worth in American football?
funFact: A touchdown is 6 points. Teams can then attempt a 1-point conversion kick or a 2-point conversion play.

question: What is the highest possible break in snooker?
funFact: A maximum break of 147 means potting all 15 reds with blacks, then all the colours. It's called a 'maximum'.

question: In what year were women first allowed to compete in the Olympics?
funFact: Women first competed at the 1900 Paris Games, in tennis and golf. They were absent from the first 1896 Games.

question: What sport uses a 'puck'?
funFact: Ice hockey's rubber puck measures 3 inches in diameter and weighs 6 ounces. Pucks are frozen before games to reduce bouncing.

question: Which country hosted the 2012 Summer Olympics?
funFact: The 2012 Summer Olympics were held in London — the first city to host the modern Olympics three times (1908, 1948, 2012).

question: What does a 'hat-trick' mean in cricket?

choices.b: Three wickets in three consecutive balls

funFact: A hat-trick in cricket means three wickets with three consecutive deliveries — extremely rare and highly celebrated.

question: Who wrote 'Romeo and Juliet'?
funFact: Shakespeare wrote Romeo and Juliet around 1594–96. It remains one of the most performed plays in the world.

question: Which artist famously cut off part of his own ear?
funFact: Van Gogh cut off part of his left ear in December 1888 during a mental health episode in Arles, France.

question: Who directed the film 'Jurassic Park' (1993)?
funFact: Spielberg's Jurassic Park used groundbreaking CGI that revolutionised filmmaking. The dinosaur roar is a blend of animal sounds.

question: Who wrote the 'Harry Potter' series?
funFact: J.K. Rowling wrote Harry Potter while a single mother in Edinburgh. The manuscript was rejected by 12 publishers.

question: Who composed 'Für Elise'?
funFact: Beethoven composed Für Elise in 1810, though it wasn't published until 40 years after his death.

question: Which band performed 'Bohemian Rhapsody'?
funFact: Queen's Bohemian Rhapsody (1975) features six distinct sections. It's been named the greatest song of all time by multiple polls.

question: Who painted the Sistine Chapel ceiling?
funFact: Michelangelo painted the Sistine Chapel ceiling between 1508 and 1512, working on scaffolding while looking upward.

question: Which novel opens with the line 'Call me Ishmael'?

choices.a: The Old Man and the Sea

funFact: Moby-Dick by Herman Melville (1851) has one of the most famous opening lines in literature. Melville dedicated it to Nathaniel Hawthorne.

question: Who sang the 1982 hit 'Thriller'?
funFact: Michael Jackson's Thriller is the best-selling album of all time with over 70 million copies sold worldwide.

question: In which country is the fashion house Gucci based?
funFact: Gucci was founded in Florence, Italy in 1921 by Guccio Gucci. It's now one of the world's most valuable luxury brands.

question: Who painted 'The Starry Night'?
funFact: Van Gogh painted The Starry Night in 1889 while staying at the Saint-Paul-de-Mausole asylum in southern France.

question: Which country has the most UNESCO World Heritage Sites?
funFact: Italy leads the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites — from the Colosseum to Pompeii to the Amalfi Coast.

question: Who created the character of Sherlock Holmes?
funFact: Arthur Conan Doyle first published Sherlock Holmes in 1887. The detective has appeared in over 200 film and TV adaptations.

question: What is considered the best-selling novel of all time (excluding religious texts)?
funFact: Don Quixote by Cervantes (1605) has sold an estimated 500 million copies. It's often called the first modern novel.

question: What nationality was Pablo Picasso?
funFact: Picasso was born in Málaga, Spain in 1881. He spent most of his adult life in France and co-founded Cubism.

question: In which city is the Louvre Museum located?
funFact: The Louvre in Paris is the world's most visited art museum, welcoming around 9 million visitors a year.

question: What is the main ingredient in guacamole?
funFact: The word 'guacamole' comes from Aztec Nahuatl meaning 'avocado sauce'. Avocados ripen only after they're picked.

question: Which country invented champagne?
funFact: Champagne must legally come from the Champagne region of France. Sparkling wine from elsewhere cannot be called champagne.

question: What is the most expensive spice in the world by weight?
funFact: Saffron costs up to $5,000 per kg. Each crocus flower produces only 3 stigmas, all of which must be hand-picked.

question: Which country is the world's largest producer of coffee?
funFact: Brazil has been the world's top coffee producer for over 150 years, growing about a third of the global supply.

question: What is currently recognised as the world's hottest chili pepper?
funFact: The Carolina Reaper averages over 1.6 million Scoville Heat Units. A jalapeño, by comparison, is about 5,000 SHU.

question: Where was pizza originally invented?
funFact: Pizza originates from Naples in the 18th century. The classic Margherita was named after Queen Margherita of Savoy in 1889.

question: What alcoholic beverage is made by fermenting honey with water?
funFact: Mead is one of the oldest known alcoholic beverages, dating back over 9,000 years. It's often called 'honey wine'.

question: Which is the most consumed beverage in the world after water?
funFact: Tea is the second most consumed beverage after water. Over 3 billion cups are consumed globally every single day.

question: In which country did ramen noodles originate?
funFact: Ramen originated in China and was introduced to Japan in the early 20th century. Japan now has hundreds of regional ramen styles.

question: Where did the croissant originally come from?
funFact: The croissant evolved from the Austrian Kipferl. It was brought to France in the 1830s and became a Parisian breakfast icon.

question: How many teaspoons are in a tablespoon?
funFact: One tablespoon equals exactly 3 teaspoons — a handy kitchen conversion used in both US and UK measurements.

question: Which fruit is technically a berry, botanically speaking?
funFact: Bananas, grapes, and tomatoes are all botanical berries. Strawberries and raspberries are technically 'aggregate fruits'.

question: Which fruit floats on water because it is about 25% air?
funFact: Apples are about 25% air by volume, which is why they float — and why bobbing for apples works!

question: What is the most consumed meat in the world?
funFact: Pork is the most widely consumed meat globally, eaten by about 36% of the world's population.

question: Which country is the world's largest producer of olive oil?
funFact: Spain produces about 45% of the world's olive oil. The Jaén province alone produces more oil than Greece.

question: What does 'WWW' stand for?
funFact: Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989 at CERN in Switzerland. He never patented it, keeping it free for all.

question: Which company created the Windows operating system?
funFact: Microsoft released its first version of Windows in 1985. Windows is now used on about 75% of desktop computers worldwide.

question: Who invented the World Wide Web?
funFact: Tim Berners-Lee proposed the WWW in 1989 to share information between scientists. He deliberately kept it open-source.

question: What does 'CPU' stand for?
funFact: The CPU is the brain of a computer, executing instructions and processing data. Modern CPUs can perform billions of operations per second.

question: Which company created the Android operating system?
funFact: Google acquired Android Inc. in 2005 for about $50 million. Android is now the world's most widely used mobile operating system.

question: What programming language was created by Guido van Rossum?
funFact: Guido van Rossum created Python in 1991 and named it after 'Monty Python's Flying Circus'. It's now one of the most popular languages.

question: How many bits are in a byte?
funFact: A byte is 8 bits, allowing it to represent 256 different values (2⁸). The word 'byte' was coined in 1956.

question: What was the first commercially successful video game?
funFact: Pong was released by Atari in 1972 and became the first commercially successful arcade game. Its simple paddle mechanic was revolutionary.

question: Who co-founded Apple alongside Steve Jobs?
funFact: Steve Wozniak designed Apple's first computers. He and Jobs founded Apple in 1976, initially in Jobs's garage.

question: What does 'AI' stand for in technology?
funFact: The term 'Artificial Intelligence' was coined in 1956 by John McCarthy. Today's AI powers everything from search engines to medical diagnosis.

question: Who co-founded Microsoft alongside Bill Gates?
funFact: Paul Allen and Gates founded Microsoft in 1975. Allen came up with the company name and brought crucial early vision.

question: In what decade was the World Wide Web invented?
funFact: Tim Berners-Lee proposed the WWW in 1989, making it an 1980s invention — though it launched publicly in 1991.

question: What does 'GPS' stand for?
funFact: GPS was developed by the US military and became available for civilian use in the 1980s. It uses at least 24 orbiting satellites.

question: Which company launched the first App Store for smartphones?
funFact: Apple launched the App Store on July 10, 2008, with 500 apps. Today it hosts over 1.8 million apps.

question: What web language is primarily used to structure and display web pages?
funFact: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) was created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1991. Every web page you see is built on HTML.

question: Approximately how many transistors does a modern smartphone chip contain?
funFact: Modern chips like Apple's M-series contain over 10–20 billion transistors, each smaller than a virus.

question: What is the most widely used social media platform in the world?
funFact: Facebook (Meta) has over 3 billion monthly active users — about 37% of the world's population logs in each month.

question: In which year was the first iPhone released?
funFact: Steve Jobs unveiled the first iPhone on January 9, 2007. It sold 6.1 million units in its first year.

question: Which programming language is most commonly used for front-end web development?
funFact: JavaScript was created in just 10 days in 1995 by Brendan Eich. It's now the most widely used programming language in the world.
